Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the extent to which sanctuary jurisdictions violate the laws of the nation, as no courts have yet determined a local jurisdiction to have actually violated the specific section of U.S. code mentioned.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support because no list of jurisdictions decidedly in violation of federal law has been provided.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that sanctuary jurisdictions encourage illegal immigration and compromise the security of law-abiding citizens without providing evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation to the claim, as the term "sanctuary" is broadly applied and there is no single understanding of what constitutes a sanctuary jurisdiction.
Understate: The claim may understate the complexity of the issue, as a law professor mentioned that no state or local jurisdiction has actually violated federal laws.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing enough evidence or clear definitions to support its statements.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that no state or local jurisdiction has instituted policies that violate the specific federal laws mentioned.
